H0.text: the inner sanctuary of the parthenon where the statue of athena is located in known as the. Cellae

H1.text: the inner sanctuary of the parthenon where the statue of athena is located in known as the. Adyton

H2.text: the inner sanctuary of the parthenon where the statue of athena is located in known as the. Opisthodomos

H3.text: the inner sanctuary of the parthenon where the statue of athena is located in known as the. naos

A4.text: With very few exceptions, Greek buildings were of a peripteral design that placed the cella in the center of the plan, such as the Parthenon and the Temple of Apollo at Paestum.

A5.text: In Classical architecture, a cella (Latin for 'small chamber') or naos (from Ancient Greek  ναός (naós) 'temple') is the inner chamber of an ancient Greek or Roman temple.

A6.text: In 5th-century BC accounts of the building, the structure is simply called ὁ νᾱός (ho naos; lit. 'the temple').

A7.text: The spaces between the columns of the opisthodomos and the peristyle were walled up, though a number of doorways still permitted access.
